document.docTitle: Redescription of the Mayfly Torleya mikhaili Tiunova, 1995 (Ephemeroptera, Ephemerellidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Redescription of the Mayfly Torleya mikhaili Tiunova, 1995 (Ephemeroptera, Ephemerellidae)

emphasis.docTitle:
Redescription of the Mayfly
Torleya mikhaili Tiunova, 1995
( Ephemeroptera , Ephemerellidae )

paragraph.emphasis: Federal Scientific Center of the East Asia Terrestrial Biodiversity, FEB, RAS, Prosp. 100-letiya Vladivostoka 159, Vladivostok 690022 Russia

document.paragraph:
The author collected new material of
T. mikhaili
from different regions of the Russian Far East. Additional characteristics and illustrations are presented here for larvae and adults of the species, as well as first descriptions of the female imago and egg. This species can be distinguished from the other species of the genus in the male adult stage by the shape and configuration of male genitalia; in the larval stage by the shape and setation of larval abdominal terga and forefemora, and features of the claw; and in the egg stage by the relative width and smoothness of surface ridges. The genus
Torleya
is divided into the
major
-group and the
nepalica
-group.

Key words:
Ephemeroptera
,
Torleya
, morphology , eggs

subSubSection.paragraph:
was first described by the author (1995) from the south of the Russian Far East, based on the male adult stage, reared from a larva ( Tiunova 1995 ). At that time, only four other species of the genus were known:
Torleya nepalica ( Allen & Edmunds, 1963 )
from Nepal,
T. major ( KlapalÃ©k, 1905 )
from Europe,
T. padunica Kazlauskas, 1963
from eastern Siberia and
T. japonica Gose, 1980
from Japan. In 2004, a review of
Torleya Lestage species
was carried out that included eight valid
Torleya species
from the Palaearctic and Oriental Regions (Jacobus et al . 2004). The previous five species and three others were included:
Torleya grandipennis Zhou, Su & Gui, 2000
,
T. lutosa Kang &Yang, 1995
, and
T. naga Jacobus &McCafferty
(in Jacobus et al .), 2004. Later, in a work devoted to the revision of Ephemerellidae genera, three more species were added.
Torlyea coheri ( Allen & Edmunds, 1963 )
and
T. lacuna ( Jacobus, McCafferty & Sites, 2007 )
were moved from the genus
Crinitella Allen & Edmunds
, and
T. longforceps ( Gui, Zhou & Su, 1999 )
was transferred from the genus
Serratella Edmunds.
Torleya longforceps
was pleased in this genus on the basis of its male genitalia being similar to those of
T. coheri
,
T. lacuna
, and
T. mikhaili
. At the same time,
T. grandipennis
was moved to the genus
Hyrtanella Allen & Edmunds ( Jacobus & McCafferty 2008 )
. Currently, the genus
Torleya
includes 13 species. This includes two species based on larvae from Indiaâ
T. simbalbarensis Selvakumar, Subramanian, Martynov & Jacobus
(in Martynov et al .), 2021 and
T. dibruensis Selvakumar, Martynov & Jacobus (Martynov et al. ) 2021
âand
T. elissa ( Jacobus, Zhou & McCafferty 2009 )
from Iran, which was moved from
Serratella
by
Martynov et al . (2023)
.

The increased number of species in the genus
Torleya
over the last thirty years has been associated with the description of new species and the movement of some species from other genera. Thus, a number of morphological characters that are necessary for a diagnosis of species are often absent from earlier descriptions (Jacobus et al . 2004). Considering that since the description of
T. mikhaili
the author has collected new material of both larvae and adults from different regions of the Russian Far East, it was decided to present additional characteristics and original illustrations for larvae and adults, as well as to describe for the first time the female imago and eggs.

Diagnosis.
Torleya mikhaili
can be separated from the other species of the genus by the combination of the following characteristics. Male imago : (1) forceps segment II which has a slight distal expansion; (2) penis with elongated apical lobes rounded at the apex; (3) U-shape a median notch; (4) genital forceps segment III relatively short, length approximately 1.5â1.7 times the width. Larvae : (5) posterior margins of abdominal terga without paired tubercles; (6) forefemur with distal transverse row of long, stout and pointed setae; length of these setae Â½ of width of femur; (7) claw of fore leg with two groups of denticles; apical group with four acute and long denticles; subdistal setae absent; (8) posterolateral projection on terga IVâIX well developed; (9) posterior margins of terga IVâIX with paired submedian short, clavate setae. Eggs : (10) the ridges about 2â3 Âµm in width; (11) the surface of the ridges relatively smooth.

Female imago (in alcohol, reared from larva) ( Fig. 2 ). Length (mm): body 4.7; fore wings, 5.0; caudal filaments, 4.5. Head, thorax and abdomen yellowish brown; thorax somewhat darker than abdomen. Wings hyaline, all veins pale. Legs pale. Abdomen with eggs yellowish or brownish; abdominal sterna yellowish. Subanal plate triangular with rounded apex. Caudal filaments pale.
Male subimago (in alcohol) ( Fig. 8 ). Similar to male imago, but color of abdomen uniformly yellowish-brownish.

FIGURES 1â2 . Habitus of
Torleya mikhaili
, paratypes (material from type locality), lateral view: 1, imago male; 2, imago female; 2A, subanal plate female.

FIGURES 3â7 . Imago male of
Torleya mikhaili
, paratypes (material from type locality): 3, genitalia, ventral; 4, genitalia, dorsal; 5, penis lobes, dorsal; 6, hind wing; 7, fore wing.

FIGURES 8â9 . Habitus of

, paratypes (material from type locality): dorsal view: 8, subimago male; 9, larvae.

FIGURES 10â14 . Larvae of
Torleya mikhaili
, paratype (material from type locality): 10, head, dorsal; 11, foreleg, dorsal; 12, fore femur and tibia, dorsal; 13, fore femur, latero-dorsal; 14, fore claw. The arrow shows the long hairlike setae on the occiput.

FIGURES 15â18 . Larvae of
Torleya mikhaili
: 15, abdomen, dorsal; 16, submedian setae on posterior margins of terga; 17, abdominal sternum IX and caudal filaments; 18, setae on caudal filaments.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Habitat . Larvae and adults of
T. mikhaili
were collected in the south of the Russian Far East (Primorskiy and Khabarovskiy Territories) at the beginning Julyâmiddle of August. Larvae were collected in rivers ( Figs 27â28 ) at a depth of 30 to 100 cm. The width of the rivers in the places where larvae were collected exceeded 100 m; the length of these rivers is more than 300 km. The water temperature in this period exceeds 20â25Â°C. The larvae inhabited stone-gravel substrates with sand and detritus, mainly in slow currents.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 19â22 . Larvae of
Torleya mikhaili
: gills of I (18), II (19), III (21), and IV (22) pairs.

FIGURES 23â26 . Eggs of
Torleya mikhaili
: 23â24, general view; 25, structure of chorion micropyles; 26, polar cap. The arrow shows the micropyles (mr).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks . In an article devoted to the revision of
Torleya species
, the authors were the first to indicate China in the distribution of
T. mikhaili (Jacobus et al ., 2004)
. At the same time, when comparing larvae from Russia and China , a number of differences were noted that arose due to the absence of some morphological characteristics in the description of
T. mikhaili
. Additional data presented in this work confirm the presence of this species in China . Note that in 2020 an article was published that provided molecular data for
T. mikhaili
larvae collected in China (
Li et al. 2020
). Therefore, a goal of further research will be to collect material for the molecular study of
T. mikhaili
from Russia so those populations can be compared to their Chinese counterparts.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 27â28 . Localities of
Torleya mikhaili
, Primorskiy Kray: 27, Ussuri River; 28, Ilistaya River.

subSection.paragraph:
Currently, the fauna of the genus
Torleya
is represented by thirteen species, which can be divided into two groups, according to the presence or absence of maxillary palp in the larvae. The species
T. longforceps
is not considered here, since its larva is unknown; therefore, it cannot be assigned to any species group based on the oral apparatus of the larva.

The
major
-group includes species in which the maxillary palp is present:
Torleya coheri
( type species of the genus group
Crinitella
, now a junior synonym of
Torleya
per Jacobus & McCafferty 2008 ),
T. padunica
,
T. major
(the type species of
Torleya
),
T. dibruensis
and
T. elissa ;
and the nepalica- group includes species in which the maxillary palp is absent:
T. japonica
,
T. lacuna
,
T. lutosa
,
T. mikhaili , T. naga
,
T. nepalica
, and
T. simbalbarensis
( Allen 1980 ; Jacobus et al . 2004; Jacobus & McCafferty 2008 ;
Martynov et al. 2021
; 2023 ).

Among species of
Torleya
with available imaginal description,
T. mikhaili
is closest to the following species, which also have genital forceps segment II with a slight distal expansion:
T. japonica , T. padunica , T. coheri
, and
T. longforceps
. The male imago of
T. mikhaili
can be distinguished by the following features: penis with elongated apical lobes rounded at the apex ( Figs 3â4 ) and U-shape a median notch (in contrast to
T. japonica
penis with short apical lobes that are very sharp at the apex, Ishiwata 1987 : fig. 1; 2005: fig. 10) (in contrast to
T. coheri
and
T. longforceps
that have penis lobes short, rounded and with a V-shaped shallow, median notch;
Jacobus et al . 2007
: fig. 2;
Gui et al . 1999
: fig. 11â26E); genital forceps segment III relatively short (length approximately 1.5â1.7 times the width, as in Figs 3â4 ) (in contrast to
T. padunica
, which has genital forceps segment III relatively elongate, with a length 2 times the width; Tiunova 1995 : fig. 10).

Final instar larvae of
T. mikhaili
can be distinguished from the other
nepalica
-group species by the following characters: posterior margins of abdominal terga without paired tubercles ( Fig. 9 ) (in
T. lacuna
,
T. nepalica
and
T. simbalbarensis
terga with paired tubercles) (
Jacobus et al . 2007
: figs. 5, 7; Tong & Dudgeon 2000 : fig. 22;
Martynov et al. 2021
: fig. 19A); claw of fore leg without subdistal setae ( Fig. 14 ) (in
T. japonica
and
T. naga
claw of fore leg with subdistal setae); posterolateral projections on terga IVâIX well-developed ( Figs 9 , 15 ) (in
T. naga
posterolateral projection on terga VIIIâ IX small) (Jacobus et al . 2004: fig.7); posterior margins of terga IVâIX with paired, submedian, short, clavate setae ( Fig. 15 ) (in
T. japonica
posterior margins of terga IVâVII with short, flat, very sharp, paired dorsal spines) (Jacobus et al . 2004); the dorsum of head, thorax, legs and abdomen without numerous bubble-like setae ( Figs 10, 11 ) (in contrast to
T. lutosa
) ( Kang & Yang 1995 : fig. 7I).

At the present time, eggs of
Torleya species
are described only for
T. lutosa , T. naga , T. nepalica
,
T. major
and
T. coheri .
The eggs of all these species are very similar and have ovoid shape, with a polar cap composed of dense threads, a chorion with a geometric macrorelief constituted of large-meshed reticulations with relatively deep mesh units; each mesh unit with a flat, smooth bottom. The ridges differ in width between species. In
T. mikhaili
, the ridges are about 2â3 Âµm in width; in
T. nepalica
4â8 Âµm ( Kang &Yang 1995 : fig. 21), in
T. naga
3â7 Âµm (Jacobus et al . 2004: fig. 5), in
T. lutosa
3â7 Âµm ( Kang &Yang 1995 : fig. 23), in
T. major
6â7 Âµm ( Ubero-Pascal & Puig 2009 : figs 4C, 7D), and in
T. coheri
4â5 Âµm ( Jacobus & Sartori 2004 : fig. 20). In
T. mikhaili
, the surface of the ridges is relatively smooth, and the inner margins of ridges have numerous papillae ( Fig. 25 ); in
T. nepalica
and
T. lutosa
, the ridges are granular ( Kang & Yang 1995 : fig. 21 and 23, respectively).

The author is grateful to Luke Jacobus ( Indiana University Purdue University Columbus, USA ) for remarks, comments and help during the preparation of the manuscript. The scanning electron micrographs were prepared with the help of Vitaliy Kazarin (Federal Scientific Center of the East Asia Terrestrial Biodiversity Far Eastern Branch, Russian Academy of Sciences, Vladivostok). The research was carried out within the state assignment of Ministry of Science and Higher Education of the Russian Federation (theme No. 124012400285-7).
